Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Cognitive Ethnographies of Engineering Design

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is to to understand the design practices of contemporary engineering workplace and to understand how the design process is organized. A related purpose is to understand how professional practices relate to nominally similar practices in university engineering classes, and how any continuities and discontinuities between work and school might inform efforts to design engineering classes. These objectives are being accomplished through an exploratory, comparative, field-based ethnographic study of the design practices of professional engineers versus engineering students. Researchers are observing practicing engineers in the workplace - what they do, who they communicate with, what they say, and how they are organized. The results of the research will be the documentation and analysis of these observations.

The primary benefits of this research come in two areas: First, current theories of engineering design can be tested for validity against real data on what real engineers do every day. Second, education of engineers can be enhanced by preparing students more directly for what they will be doing in the workplace.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goals of this project were to: 1) understand the design practices of contemporary engineering workplace and educational settings and to understand how the design process is organized, and 2) understand how professional practices relate to nominally similar practices in the undergraduate and graduate curriculum, and how any continuities and discontinuities between work and school might inform efforts to design engineering curricula. Research findings have advanced our understanding of how professional engineers practice engineering within engineering firms, how engineering students are taught to practice engineering, and how these approaches to engineering design differ. 


Significant results have pointed to the spatiotemporal organization in engineering design. Results have also shown that the idealized “design loop” taught to all engineering undergraduates does not truly capture the complexity of how design is done. For example, often class projects are simply a vehicle for hands-on learning without the organization structure (e.g., machine shop, test support, etc.) necessary for successful translation of ideas into practice; or authenticity as compared to industry settings. The reality in design is that a multitude of factors, including organizational time and space structures, shape the way engineers design systems.


This research has begun to show how professional design engineers supplement their academic training to meet the needs of the workplace. In doing so, we are contributing to an important emerging line of work that aims to better prepare engineering students for industry. For engineers-in-the-making, closing gaps between their educations and their early workplace experience can promote an earlier understanding of what their futures hold, help them to learn the truly important disciplinary and practical knowledge they will use in their future work, and secure a more authentic identification with the discipline and profession of engineering.
